pullRequest.body:
Following discussion at #11313 this is an attempt to refactor `Algebra/Group/AddChar.lean` such that `AddChar A M` is a structure in its own right rather than a type synonym for `Multiplicative A â†’* M`. 

We also relax typeclass assumptions considerably (only assuming commutativity, etc, where it is really needed) and add some new functionality, e.g. composition with monoid morphisms on either side (`MonoidHom.compAddChar` and `AddChar.compAddMonoidHom`).

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: The PR description is outdated as it still mentions `comp_monoidHom`

> The PR description is outdated as it still mentions `comp_monoidHom`

I have no idea what you mean there. There never was a `comp_monoidHom`; probably you mean `comp_addMonoidHom`. You suggested a renaming from `monoidHom_comp` to `monoidHomComp`, which would probably have also entailed renaming `comp_addMonoidHom` to `compAddMonoidHom` although you did not explicitly say this; but in any case I disagreed with the suggestion (giving reasons, see above) and I have not implemented it. So nothing is outdated. (There was a typo in the PR description which I have corrected.)
Ah sorry, it's hard to navigate the PR on the mobile app. Anyway, you should comply with the casing convention.

> To me, it is still more natural to _define_ them as homs to the add-version of the codomain.

So far, they are actually defined as homs from the mul-version of the domain. What I do like about this refactor is that it restores some symmetry, which is broken by the decision to change from additive to multiplicative in the domain rather than from multplicative to additive in the codomain.

I'm going to maintainer merge this PR, as I think the points that were raised have been addressed.
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by MichaelStollBayreuth.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8314227649/job/22751150534)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8314227649/job/22751150831)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8314227649/job/22751150230)
Modulo the comment on `toMonoidHom_apply`, I think this looks good.

I am fine with most changes, apart from some comments. But I come back to my question in the previous PR, as I am not entirely sure that defining this structure is really the best approach. It puts a lot of focus on the distinction between "additive" and "multiplicative"  structures, which are generally treated on an equal footing in mathlib, the difference being most of the time only of syntactic, rather than semantic, nature. To me, it is still more natural to *define* them as homs to the add-version of the codomain.
Modulo the comment on `toMonoidHom_apply`, I think this looks good.

```suggestion
  /-- The underlying function.
  
  Do not use this function directly. Instead use the coercion coming from the `FunLike`
  instance. -/
```

```suggestion
  /-- The function maps `0` to `1`.
  
  Do not use this directly. Instead use `AddChar.map_zero_one`. -/
```

```suggestion
  /- The function maps addition in `A` to multiplication in `M`.
  
  Do not use this directly. Instead use `AddChar.map_add_mul`. -/
```

This doesn't seem to match conventions elsewhere in the library, e.g. [ContinuousAt.comp_continuousWithinAt](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/ContinuousOn.html#ContinuousAt.comp_continuousWithinAt). (There is no object called a `MonoidHomComp`.)
(Perhaps this shouldn't be in the `AddChar` namespace at all, but should be called `MonoidHom.comp_addChar`?)

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ```
Not sure whether this should really be a `simp`  lemma: it does not hurt much but I am not sure the LHS is more complex than the RHS.
OK, fair point

Isn't it a bit asymmetric that for the map to ` Multiplicative A -> M`  we only have the equivalence and for the other one both? Perhaps it is enough to pack `toAddMonoidHom` in the equivalence and use that when needed.
Fair enough, we can have `toAddMonoidHom` as a separate def, we may as well maintain symmetry.

... I went to add this and realised it was already there? We have all four of `toAddMonoidHom`, `toAddMonoidHomEquiv`, `toMonoidHom`, and `toMonoidHomEquiv`. 

The one thing that is asymmetric is `toMonoidHomMulEquiv` (upgrading the `Equiv` to a `MulEquiv`) but that is because the choice to write the group law on `AddChar`'s as multiplication breaks the symmetry. I suppose we could have `toAddMonoidHomAddEquiv : Additive (AddChar A M) â‰ƒ+ (A â†’+ Additive M)` but I'm not sure how likely this is to be useful.
I agree, probably not too useful.
I added it anyway, for the following reason: it will make life easier if YaÃ«l carries through his plan to rewrite `AddChar A M` as an additive rather than multiplicative monoid.
Again for this one, I am not sure whether it should be a `simp`.
The LHS involves the monoid structure on `AddChar A M`, the RHS only the monoid structure on `M`, so I think it is fair to describe the RHS being simpler.

I see what you mean, but I wonder (and really have no strong opinion) if for the user seeing all the LHS become the RHS is what is hoped for. Of course one can always revert or use a `simp only` to avoid some of these to fire, but to me both sides seem of potentially equal utility.
I'm thinking of this as a modified version of things like `Pi.add_apply` etc, which are all `simp`s.
Why do you want to remove this?
I'm not removing it, just moving it to a different section since it is valid under weaker typeclass assumptions (the definition makes sense without needing to assume that `A` or `M` to be a group).
Oh, I did not find the moved version, that's why I was asking. Sorry for the noise.
Should an empty line be added here (and similarly below), to get a separate paragraph in the docstring as shown on hover or in the HTML docs?
There was originally, but the linter flags it as a formatting error. EDIT: I added them back and the linter didn't complain (I think maybe I had `/-` instead of `/--` last time)
Shouldn't the last `a` be of type `A` instead of `Mulitplicative A`? My understanding is that defeq abuse should be avoided in statements.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - refactor(Algebra/Group/AddChar): reimplement using structures
